text: Nice use of stairwell!
I'm kinda working on building an EDH deck around every Theros god and I was kinda stuck with Pharika, who just seemed horrible. But then someone suggested the card and it's so cool.
Pharika could have given you the token no matter what graveyard you hit and she still wouldn't be in the top 10 of Theros gods
Great looking card, just too bad about the design. I ran her out of stubbornness in Glissa forever
I like trying to find ways to make her useable though
There's nothing interesting about the 10,000th Purphuros token deck, where as I'll always check out Pharika lists I see
This is exactly what I told someone as well. Literally. Even if she gave you the token, there would still be quite a few gods still stronger than her,
What do you guys think of Mogis and how would ou approach him?
I have a creatureless Mogis Punisher deck.
Mostly enchantments
Sounds sweet. Is there an online list that I could look at?
Yeah, it's pretty outdated, though
I'll see if my friend Chris has his online. It's all just punishment stuff. It's the deck he uses for last game of the night since it creates a clock state immedietly.
Oh, wow, maybe not.
Basically any effect that damages everyone he runs, with a goal of being just slightly ahead enough to end the game with an earthquake or something that leaves him at 4 when everyone else dies
Just looked through my decks on Tappedout. It's not there.
I don't run earthquake, actually.
Or Exsanguinate
I'm considering trying to make room for Torment of Hailfire.
Torment has been busted in my Glissa deck
I did run Tectonic Break, then cut it for Desolation.
Well, not busted. Just great.
I wasn't​ very original and just slammed it into Tasigur. That was my Prerelease promo
I also have yet to do the Iroas deck as well. I think I'll have that one be a Boros Angel deck, focused on combat (who'd have thought)
I think new neheb makes Iroas decks way better now
I picked up a [[Yuan Shao, the Indecisive]] a few years ago intending to make Iroas but never did

text: Can't imagine why...
Didn't know he sees play though, that's nice
Yeah I think he's amazing as a mono red general. Way more interesting to play than purphoros or krenko.
It's the first time I've seen him played in standard, but it was awesome watching
But then I pay about...zero attention to stadnrad
Because it's boring af

Plus, with as much as i get to play Magic in general, standard is not in anyway worth keeping up with. It's fun to watch now and then, but since I don't plan on playing on the Pro Tour I just don't have the motivation
Oh look, the one deck that is good is doing well. Let's watch it play all day against itself and the couple of folks that decided not to run it.
If I get to a competitive REL event once a month that's a TON. I'd rather shoot the shit playing other formats.
Standard is more narrow now than it has ever been. I play edh because it's basically fixed legacy.
There's room for creativity and growth. We get to experiment and create. All of the other formats are just too restrictive to be interesting to me anymore.

Ha, I dunno man, Legacy is so whacky and open. If you're playing competitive EDH you may as well play legacy. If you're playing casual Legacy you may as well play EDH. And if you play Tiny Leaders you should stop.

I like the idea of having a "leader" that decides what you're going to be using. Also the somewhat  casual setting.

That's also why I usually build around the commander, I love if it has an impact
It's also very cool to see all kinds of new cards you didn't know about
It's hard for me to agree that there isn't room for creativity in legacy. When you see people winning events playing [[false cure]] and [[skyshroud cutter]] that says the opposite to me

text: Legacy allows for creativity but outside of the top 3 decks you're basically just going for style points.
Honest question, do you play very much legacy?
Playing Squirrel Opposition
Not in the past six months but I've played legacy since 2003.
Ok
The decks exist. I stopped on mono green trinisphere. It could win but you're kidding yourself if you think the cute decks hang with bug or miracles in terms of consistency.
It's like playing skred in modern. It can win but it isn't deaths shadow or jund. It's just not.
Well Miracles doesn't really exist anymore. But I could rattle off 10 decks that could win any given event for legacy which doesn't happen in any other 60-card format.
<http://mtgtop8.com/format?f=LE>
Yep. 2 decks over 10%
Right now legacy has a huge slant towards grixis and for good reason. I'm sure those 10 decks are good, but are they good enough to breach that chunk of the meta? No.
5% beyond the nearest competitor is worth noting. I'm not trying to say the format sucks, but it's far from creative.

I'm going to have to agree to disagree again. If you know how to navigate the format with your deck you have just as much chance as any other deck. Grixs probably has the largest player base and is most represented because it's what the pros call the "best deck" so people just default to it.
It's just like EDH too, there is always some amount of RNG going on too.

Well there's not much point in going deeper into this. I've top 8'd a ptq with rakdos skred in modern so I'm aware of how much being comfortable with your deck can make a difference. It doesn't indicate or prove a format fosters creativity. It just doesn't. You can do the same thing in modern but that doesn't make that format creative either. Follow the leader syndrome does play a part, but a large chunk of it has nothing to do with that. I respect your opinion though. As long as you enjoy it and have fun with it that's really all that matters.
Deal
Also, miracles had 2 of the top 8 in Prague last month, so that deck is far from dead. That tourney had almost 300 participants. Mentor Miracles is for real.

This is tangential at best but one thing I have noticed is that players rarely mistake good in edh for good in other formats but they do much more frequently confuse good in their legacy format with good in edh
That's a pretty fair point. I've noticed quite a bit of that in my meta.

Perhaps as a companion to that I also see much more frequently people in edh confuse generically good with good in my deck where as that doesn't really happen elsewhere I.e I see people just jamming deadeye into decks where it barely accomplishes anything or putting crucible in a two color deck with 1 fetch
People who don't play edh think [[Providence]] is an edh card

text: EDH curves have gone drastically down since I started playing in 2010
7 Mana better damn well win you the game at this point
Yeah j, because grounded decks can win by default if the competition is too slow.
Inbalance in power level is the worst experience in Commander now
My shop games still run pretty long but there's a lot less room for just blindly running bad cards
I mean I won two games with djeru last week so it's not like people just combo out on turn five, but if you don't have a plan you're just not competing
Agreed, I wish there were an objective scale on power level, would really decrease the salt that can result from inbalanced games

My big thing on power level differences and differing expectations for games every time we have this conversation goes back to just communicating with the other players to see what they're trying to do/expectations are and adjusting from ther
Just some preemptive small talk beofre the games will tip you off to what deck to grab more times than not

I tend to be drawn to weak commanders and pick a wonky theme but then tweak the deck hard. Yeah my Reki deck is fairly tight but it's Reki history of kamagaeq. Nobody really cares about a moat in Isperia sphinx tribal
So much of what matts wrote
Oh yeah that's for sure. The players at my LGS that I've played with for years I know what to expect, but it's hard for new players to adjust
My glissa deck works well but people don't complain because I'm limited entirely to creatures with death touch
Plus you wanna be extra careful with noobs not to scare them off the format
checking in late, I have a mogis discard deck
with worldgorger dragon combo as the finisher
doesn’t power it out though
I run my LGS's league and scaring off noobs is one of my biggest worries
Ha, if I lost to Worldgorger I don't think I could allow myself to be mad about that
I mean, I could easily power out the combo too, with entomb and way more enablers
Me and a couple of friends actually have some hand signals for if we're gonna intentionally throw a game to a new player
buuuuuuut I don’t
I like spectors

Yeah, my LGS has recently started a commander night. It's been going pretty well and we get a large variety of players. There were a few issues because the store was giving a small amount of store credit for winning pods, which incentivized people to bring out tuned decks. They changed that, those people went away and it's been great
Doesn't come up that often but sometimes it's worth it as a long term investment
Is it "*point to new kid* *pound fist into palm*, or else!"
Exactly that. We're subtle.
Deal. It's all about the nuance
"Oh I guess I can't block that Craw Wurm". Sigh. Fold.
We don't have any incentive to win outside holding a sweet wrestling belt

I can do SUPER broken sign language so when <@U4BFDSLKT>  and I are trying to do something it can get entertaining. We used to play all sorts of card games with hidden signals. One ended with him slapping our friend in the face about 5 times
<@U3NH6MY1X>
everyone loves World Title Belts
Oh I know, that's why I did it
Custom made and everything
Nice
Hahaha awesome
If you're curious, you can see it on the website I also run, check out champions: <https://www.edhchicago.com>

text: Nice. I know a couple of places here in Dallas are doing edh leagues with points based systems that penalize degenerate play. For instance, you could win the pod but come up negative on points if you were playing Narset turns and took too many turns to get there (iirc you lose points for each turn beyond the first extra turn). It seems to do a decent job of checking degenerate play.
Ah, you're in Dallas, <@U6LUSCS1J>? I'm in Austin.
My wife goes up to Dallas for training over the summers so I'm up there a bit.
Yep. That's cool. Next time you're up ping me. We can meet up and play at Madness in Plano.
David Williams still comes in and plays occasionally.
Sorry, I don't know who that is...
World series of poker champ and former pro magic player.
So does he always want to play EDH with ante?
Infamous for being booted from the pro tour for having 4 foil fact or fictions in his deck while all other cards were normal. Card marking was the call.
Lmao he doesn't play edh that I know of.
I've pondered whether or not I should have him sign a foil fact or fiction, but you'd have to be a dinosaur of magic for it to be funny. That happened way back in the early 2000's iirc.
<http://archive.wizards.com/sideboard/article.asp>
<http://archive.wizards.com/sideboard/article.asp?x=Worlds2001%5C466williamsdq>

attachments.title: 2001 World Championships Coverage
attachments.text: Sideboard Online Event Coverage
attachments.fallback: 2001 World Championships Coverage

text: There we go.
My bad it was accumulated knowledge not fact or fiction.
So the weight difference was enough for him to detect it by touch?
More like he wasn't using sleeves and the difference in thickness allowed him to shuffle and cut them to the top.
Oh the wild west days of competitive magic...
Yeah it was super shady. He was the biggest magic name in North Texas back then so it was huge when he got kicked off the tour. He's a nice guy though.
Can't be that nice if he's willing to cheat.
Truth
Maybe he was just testing the limits of the rules. Was it known that that would be cheating back in the day?
Technically he was using unaltered cards printed by WotC that were tournament legal in a vacuum
Aren't some FTV foils not tournament legal even right out of the box because of curling issues? Am I misremembering that?
I don't know is if there is a famous case of it, but I wouldn't doubt it
Read the article I linked to from the wizards archives. They were the only foils in the deck and the circumstances of him getting caught were pretty damning. He knew what he was doing.
Oh, I'm not saying he didn't know what he was doing.
Just that he didn't alter cards to make cheat. Everything he was using was *technically* a legal card. In a vacuum.
Sure. Wizards is the one who made the card "illegal" by their standards. He just was using what they made
Right. He didn't "cheat" he just...used what was available to his greatest advantage. Was this when WotC made this a rule? Had anyone tried it before?
It wouldn't matter - it certainly went against the spirit of the game by trying to gain an unfair advantage.
Cue him leaving like randy marsh "I'M SORRY I THOUGHT THIS WAS AMERICA!"
Yeah and he broke the unwritten rule that makes cheating ok in America. He got caught.

To answer the question, yes this what caused wizards to make the official rule regarding the issue. I see what you're saying Dean, and at the time a lot of pros stood with him when he was kicked off the tour for a year.

So a nice reader commented on my article to make a deck around [[act of Treason]] effects that was tribal. I'm not sure exactly why but the first thing that came to mind was Kess wizards with a heavy focus on treason effects. What do you guys think?

Whenever Arashin Foremost enters the battlefield or attacks, another target Warrior creature you control gains double strike until end of turn.
_"I would gladly give my life if it would inspire my clan to victory."_
*2/2*
attachments.title: Arashin Foremost {1}{W}{W}

text: Tithe is super sweet. Very underrated card.
